messageBody:
Luiz Siqueira Neto wrote:

> --- In junit@yahoogroups.com <mailto:junit%40yahoogroups.com>, "J. B.
> Rainsberger" <jbrains762@...> wrote:
> >
> > Luiz Siqueira Neto wrote:
> >
> > > > Why do you create your own collection methods? Why do you not
> use List,
> > > > Set and Map from the Java collections library? The tedious part
> is when
> > > > you duplicate existing features, not because of testing. :)
> > > >
> > > > Good luck.
> > >
> > > My collection is persistent and I use annotation reflection inside it.
> >
> > Perhaps I don't know your persistence tool. Which one do you use? Can
> > you annotate only the item to persist the collection?
>
> I create a concept - well... if it is possible - of entities,
> containers and state machines: With "entities" I define a business
> logic; the "container" is a collection of "entities", it is a "entity"
> too; the "state machine" is responsible by create and use GUIs,
> DataBases, reports, etc...
> The "state machine" implement a "factory pattern", it receive as
> parameter a "entity" or a "container of entities" and than build GUIs,
> DataBases, wherever...
> The "state machine" have a "indexed property", than I need check if
> this property is correctly populated. That is the problem, is really
> painfully do this kind of test for all new state machine. Maybe
> generics solve my problem.
>
> If you have some idea I really like to listen.
>
> Thanks about our time. :)

You are welcome. I have one question: did you implement this
successfully for any specific case yet? Your ideas sound very general,
and I worry that you are thinking too generally too quickly. I recommend
you start with one specific case of an entity first, then show that you
need the container and state machine. I find it easier to prove a design
decision with a specific case than with the general case.

Good luck.
